Was she who nearest had oblig'd your Soul?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: I said it, and I thought it.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Did you not promise to reside in Scythia?
And to engage your Friend to do the like?
That with the Service of your Life you might
Return me, Thanks for the rich Present made you?
Were not these very Words your own?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: They were.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then think of thy base Flight, if thou dar'st think of it,
And say, thou art not a Hypocrite.
What canst thou answer to thy just Accuser?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: That which will make my Accuser say, she wrongs me.
You accuse me that I wou'd have fled: Indeed
I attempted to regain that Liberty,
Of which your Pow'r unjustly had depriv'd me.
What Reason cou'd you find, insulting Queen,
To make them Captives whom the Gods made free,
And gave them Souls deserving Liberty?
As against Nature's Laws we are your Victims,
Against the Right of Nations we're your Captives;
And any way was lawful to fair Liberty,
Which we were born for, and for which we'll die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: That very Moment I restor'd your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Indeed you did restore it, but on Terms
Impossible to be perform'd by us.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why did you then approve them?

sp.speaker: Phel.
sp.p: I never knew them well till I had left you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: A meer Pretence! Is Grecian Faith so known?
Had not you giv'n that Faith to remain here?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: But then that Faith was on Conditions giv'n;
Which soon I found you never cou'd perform.

sp.speaker: Queen,
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Because the Gift you offer'd, was no Gift.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What was no Gift? The Present which you priz'd so!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Had it been real, it had been inestimable.
You only gave me Words, and the vain Promise
Of what the Gods had taken from your Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Surely thou ravest,
Is not Diana's Priestess in my Pow'r?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Her Body is; but tho' it be a glorious One
Without her Soul, I wou'd refuse the Treasure:
But love alone can of her Soul dispose;
And, without leave obtain'd of you,
The God had frankly done it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Ha! To whom!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: How fain you wou'd extort this Secret from me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How fain I wou'd? by Heav'n I will extort it.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: You never shall; I know I am to bleed,
And with me too the fatal Truth shall die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then 'tis no Truth, and thou wilt die a Villain:
Die with the Brand of an ungrateful Traytor,
An odious Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: To be reveng'd for these opprobrious Wrongs,
I need but tell you what you ask, proud Princess.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Do it then.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Will you persist to urge me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I will. The Priestess! Who has touch'd her Heart?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: In your own Breast the fatal Secret's lodg'd.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Lodg'd in my Breast!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Ask, ask your self the Question, who is he
Who finds the way of touching Scythian Hearts?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ha! Gods! That stings.
Here Guards, withdraw your Pris'ner,
And bring Diana's Priestess hither instantly.
By yon Bright Goddess, He's come off with Honour.
But Oh, the exalted Virtue of his Friend!
Who freely for his Friend can Life resign,
And for his Mistress can contemn a Crown!
This Raises him still more in my Esteem.
It wou'd do, had he made a better Choice.
And is the Priestess then preferr'd to me?
Have I, who have had the Ambition to behold
Admiting Monarchs at my Feet adoring,
Liv'd to reflect, with mortifying Soul,
That I my self, to one unknown, have offer'd,
And been, O Gods! by one unknown refus'd?
And for Diana's Priestess too refus'd!
Refus'd! Scorn'd! loath'd! Oh, how that tears my Heart!
But if thou hast a Soul, with treble Scorn
Return it: Suffer him to take this Priestess;
And let his despicable Choice revenge thee.
What! must he gain her by the odious Boast,
That he has sacrific'd me to my Creature?
And can I suffer it? I cannot think of it
Without Distraction. But the Priestess comes.
So; From whence come you? Ha! whence these Disorders?
What makes you tremble? And what strikes you dumb?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: To such a haughty and insulting Look
I have not learnt to answer.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I look, as it becomes me, on my Slave.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The sight of such a Slave shou'd make you humble,
By shewing you to what excess of Wretchedness
The Daughter of a mighty King may fall.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Say, From whence come you? I command you answer.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I have no Pow'r to speak.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: So hasty was your Flight?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Who must not fly from acting Cruelties,
At which Barbarity it self can melt?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh, how those meek and melting Words
Become the soft and tender Race of Tantalus!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The Race of Tantalus has been revengeful:
But yet it ne'er was bloody unprovok'd.
What have these Grecians done to me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What hadst thou done t' assembled Greece at Aulis?
What hadst thou done to thy own Father there?
Who to thy Ruin, unprovok'd, consented;
Nay, pressed it, urg'd it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: My Mother urg'd it not.
I from the Heroines of our Race have learnt
To shew soft Pity.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou from the Heroines of thy Race hast learnt,
Thou hast, fond Maid, to shew a guiltier Passion.
Oh, how their kind Reception of their Guests
Had made their Names throughout the World renown'd!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: For an Example of such kind Reception,
Perhaps I need not fly to Greece.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I understand thee well.
Plagu'd by the Terrors of impending Wrath,
Thou would'st provoke and hasten Death, thou would'st,
And have him swifter that he may be gentler,
But know, fond Maid, thou shalt not die so early,
Think of thy Gratitude to thy Preserver,
And think what that deserves.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: My preserver!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Was ever such audacious insolence?
Who was it sav'd thee from immediate Death,
At thy Arrival on the State of Tauris?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Would I had been a Man at that Arrival,
For then my Blood had stain'd your cruel Altars!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O wretch, ingrateful to that black Degree,
As to disown the mighty Obligation,
By which thou liv'st to save thou art not oblig'd!
Would'st thou insinuate that thy Sex preserv'd thee?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Men are the Victims that your Goddess claims!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Not always.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Tradition says so, and your bloody Rites
Are founded on Tradition.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: When she her self declares her awful Will,
Tradition's of no force.
But not the feeble voice of faint Tradition;
No, the loud call of the descending Goddess,
Claim'd thee at Aulis her devoted Victim,
At least so Calchas said.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The fraud of Calchas plainly she Detected,
By suffering me to evade th'inhuman Altar.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: 'Twas Clytemnestra's Sacrilege preserv'd thee,
And not the Goddess;
Who wracking thee on this her sacred Shore,
Strongly appears to Redemand her Fugitive.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Before these Grecians came you had no such thoughts.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, thy soft graceful look, and seeming innocence,
Inclin'd me to suspect the crafty Calchas.
But thy black Guilt appearing with thy Ingratitude,
Makes me repent of my mistaken pity.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O fatal pity▪ Rightly term▪ d mistaken?
True pity would have suffered me to bleed;
Then I had been at rest in the Dark Grave,
With my unhappy Parents!
Not have convers'd with everlasting woe,
In you Dire Tabernacle of Despair!
For there no smiling Beam of Joy is seen;
No gladsom sound is ever heard,
But all is always rueful Lamentation,

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If thuo'rt so sensible of this,
Then know that there's a punishment preparing for thee,
A punishment that's worthy thy perfidiousness.
If 'tis so terrible to see these Sights,
So woful but to hear these sounds of Sorrow,
What must it be to act the bloody Office?
What must it be to one who has a Soul
As soft as thine, as melting ev'n as Mercies,

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah miserable me!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: To act it, nay, and act it on a Grecian?
One who himself has only tender thoughts,
Or only tender Thoughts at least towards thee.
One who perhaps could die for thee, for whom
Perhaps ev'n thou could'st die?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah Gods!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: See how her Soul declares its weakness,
And now unable to contain its grief,
Pours forth a Deluge of Impetuous Sorrow!
What must it be to think the Dreadful time
Of doing this accursed Deed approaches!
That the next Moment thou must stain thy Hands,
By going to his Heart a cursed way?
While thy Soul hears th'intolerable Sound
Of his last dying Groans, and sees his Eyes.
His Trembling dying Eyes, that in Deaths cruel'st pangs
Look kindly up, as if they blest their Murtherer?
Go bring the Eldest of the Captives hither,
sp.stage: To some of the Guards who go out.
sp.l: Priestess alone, I leave thee with thy Lover,
But know thy Conference with him must be short;
And know that yet 'tis in thy power to save him.
But let not pass the irrevocable Moment;
Think that the next comes hurrying on, and then
Unless thou first perswad'st him to abandon thee,
Thou shalt behold him to the Altar drag'd,
Where by thy Hand he dies, and when that's done,
Thou, Thou shalt by the sacred Steel expire,
Thou the devoted Victim of the Goddess.
Guards! On your Lives, observe them at a distance.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Inhuman Queen! Must I not only lose him,
But must I urge him to forsake me? No,
Alas thou need'st not urge him,▪ that assure thy self;
For what would'st thou perswade him to?
To avoid Death, and to embrace a Crown?
A little argument will there prevail,
But the Queen says 〈…〉, is 〈…〉?
No, 'tis the Vision of a 〈…〉 Woman.
But say it should be true, forbid it Gods▪
Oh should He love me, 〈…〉 taste of misery,
Which ev'n in this 〈…〉▪
For I could die 〈…〉 he lost me,
How can I plead 〈…〉 my self successfully?
How can I e'er find 〈…〉 can perswade him
To make another Happy 〈…〉 thought!
To make another Happy▪ and me Miserable?
I cannot, I can see him 〈…〉 first.
Perish! By whom! Ah watch! Inhuman wretch!
And canst thou then at last resolve to Murder him?
See where He comes, and with a Look so sweet,
As might disarm ev'n Death, ye Gods, ye Gods,
Who have resolved that I must be a wretch,
Beyond whatever Mortal was before;
Take care that I prevail to my undoing,
And give me strength enough to court Despair.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Madam, I come to hear your last Commands,
Let them be what they will, yet I with Joy am come.
But why upon this lovely Brow,
So black a cloud of Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Oh could you see my Heart▪ and all the Horrour
Which wildly rages there, how would you pity me?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Alas! ev'n now I pity thee!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, from my very Soul, you cannot think
How much Compassion tears my tortur'd Heart.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Make hast then, and prevent the cursed Blow,
That I'm compell'd to strike.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Had I a Dagger, I would do it instantly.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: There is an easier way at least to you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Grecians abhor.
That Virgins of Affairs like this should speak,
You have beheld 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Wherefore 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Too well 〈…〉
And would not 〈…〉
Which I can never 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Then I am 〈…〉
But why should you 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Reason and Justice 〈…〉
I love another.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha! Then his fatal 〈…〉
What ground the Queen had for her strange suspicion.
You love another?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O more than Life, you see I love another.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: That let me Hide ev'n from 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ha! Why should you conceal it from her?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Ask me no more.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I must, and you must answer.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: She is my Mortal Enemy.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can any Woman prove a Mortal Enemy▪
To one who loves like you?
Your passion known perhaps had made her kind.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: 'Tis to avoid her kindness ● conceal it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: T'avoid it?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: More than Ten Thousand Deaths I dread her kindness

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: You love your Enemy, and dread her Kindness?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: She is by force, and 〈…〉 Choice my Enemy
She pities me, ev'n from her 〈…〉
Yet my hard Fate compells her to be cruel to me
But ye Gods!
How much I suffer from 〈…〉
Than from her Cruelty 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O Heaven and Earth, I tremble least the Queen
Had but too just a ground for her suspicion.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Who can see her, he Loves in Grief,
And bear an equal Mind?
How might my Passion known, augment her Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But what can force her since she is so tender,
T'appear your Mortal Enemy?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why should you ask! Your questions but disturb me!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I ask to save you, and I must be answer'd;
Speak, what can force her, since she is so tender,
T'appear your Mortal Enemy?
〈…〉 Thoughts in me,
〈…〉 l Deed.
〈…〉 Fury that thou dream'st not of.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Gods! Am I 〈…〉 who loves me!
〈…〉 these Convulsions?
〈…〉 Suppose that you were forc'd
〈…〉 wou'd it not shake you?
〈…〉 Murther,
〈…〉 say,
〈…〉 Heart?
〈…〉 you
〈…〉 obey?
sp.p: 〈…〉 like a Fury?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: 〈◊〉, how that stings ●●▪

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha! what, you 〈◊〉 and tremble, and turn pale!
When the bare mention works on you so terribly.
Can I endure the thing?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Pow'r that you adore, and that commands it,
Will calm, and will support you.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What if one God commands the dreadful Deed?
Perhaps another mightier Pow'r forbids it;
And if I do it, 〈…〉
Not to be born 〈…〉
Without Despair and 〈…〉
Which then shall I 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Which of 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Thou ask'st 〈…〉
His awful Name's 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: When 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ev'n now 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Here, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Here?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Here, look 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Is ' he not manifest 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Oh astonishment!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: If thou art blind, 〈…〉
Know, that thou feel'st 〈…〉
And own'st his dreadful 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Amasement!
And canst thou be so infinitely 〈…〉
To love this▪ Object of Divine Displeasure 〈…〉
Oh this pathetick Silence how it 〈…〉
How this Disorder in thy 〈…〉
And quite destroys my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Cou'd you see all the 〈…〉
Cou'd you behold my Heart 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I have been shewn 〈…〉
And in that Sight I saw a 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Think what's to 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I do, I do, my Soul's 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Reflect upon my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Damnation! 〈…〉
And what must I endure!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Have Mercy then upon yourself and me.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O for a Dagger!
That plunging it in my Heart's Blood,
I might to both shew Mercy.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: That Thought's a Dagger; there's another way.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: No!
My Heart, my Life, my very▪ Soul is yours:
My Honour and my Virtue are the Gods:
They are Depositums entrusted with me;
And I'll, untouch'd, with my last Breath restore them.
〈…〉 Grecian, the Queen has sent us to inform thee,
That thy Delay has mortally offended her;
And Death and Vengeance chase thee now in view.
Here, you must to the Temple guard the Priestess.
And you in Iron Bonds must bind the Pris'ner:
Then lead him where the Ministers expect him,
To bind his Temples, and to veil his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Stay but one Moment, when a Wretch requires it,
The only happy Moment I ere knew.

sp.speaker: 1 Scyth.
sp.l: We dare not; for severely we're forbidden.
The Grecians who were seen upon the Beach,
With their drawn Weapons 〈…〉
And if thou shouldst 〈…〉
The Queen has sworn 〈…〉
That we shall all of us 〈…〉
D'y ' hear? We 〈…〉
The Cornets with their 〈…〉
Bind him, you Slaves 〈…〉
How dare you stand 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: My Grecians 〈…〉
I'd give the World 〈…〉
But since it will 〈…〉
I ask not Liberty, 〈…〉
I ask not ev'n a 〈…〉
Pour down your Plagues on my devoted Head,
Torment me, rack me, tear me,
Torture me any way, unless by torturing he●●
Comfort her poor afflicted Heart, ye Pow'rs!
And grant, that at our next accursed meeting,
Grant, cruel Gods, that mine be all the Pain.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Break Heart, that we may never meet again.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: SAve us ye eternal Pow'rs that save the Just.

sp.speaker: 2 Priest.
sp.p: Protect us, great Diana!

sp.speaker: 1 Priest.
sp.p: What dismal Night is this?

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.p: A dreadful Night indeed!

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: Sure all the Elements will now be wrack'd,
And 'tis the end of all things.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Are you the Sacred Ministers of Heav'n,
And yet afraid of Thunder?

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: When Jove's disturb'd, what Mortal dares be calm?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I who am conscious of committing nothing,
That may provoke his Anger.
Are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: They are, ev'n now th'adorn the fatal Image.
〈…〉 Grecians are 〈…〉 And is it possible?
〈…〉 could they force in spight of your resistance,
〈…〉 up the Mountain's Steep ascent?
〈…〉 You have heard how first by slow Degrees they ascended,
While as they mounted dusky Clouds arose
And Heaven appear'd to s●o●l upon th' Attempt,
And lowring blacken'd all their March, while ours
Upon the Margin of the horrid Summet,
With threatning Dares impatiently expected them.
But when within our Javelins reach they arriv'd
Upon the sudden Jove declar'd aloud for them.
The dreadful Thunder from behind them roar'd,
While at our Scythians Eyes the blasting Lightning flew,
The Grecians with a shout that breath'd Defiance,
Receiv'd th' Auspicious Signal; and the Thunder
Seem'd as an Instrument of War t'excite them.
Hear ye Barbarians! Hear great Jove they cryed,
Threatning Destruction to your cursed Race.
And as the Rocks Restor'd the Dreadful cry
Murmuring they clash'd a formidable Din
Upon their flaming Shields, then shook their Horrid Spears,
Their Spears that bristled with th'amazing Beams
Of the Retorted Lightning; Hideous they ascended,
As flaming Furies mounting from the Abyss,
While all our Scythians look'd like pale Offenders,
When they behold Hell's Ghastly 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Infamous Slaves 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: This front 〈…〉
Where I, great Queen, by 〈…〉
Prepar'd the 〈…〉
When lo the 〈…〉
The Mournful 〈…〉
When in 〈…〉
I hurrying drag 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: Not I 〈…〉
As we were 〈…〉
The Grecians that 〈…〉
Had driv'n our 〈…〉
And quite o'ercome 〈…〉
Swift as the Lightning 〈…〉
And in a Moment, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And thou art alive to tell this▪

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: My Life was of Importance to your Service▪
And therefore I preserv'd it.
A panick Fear had now dispers'd our Scythians▪
Some fell, some sled, but all remain'd Disorder'd.
Iby this Voice alone retriev'd the Fainting,
Confirm'd the Doubtful, and recall'd the Flying:
Rallied by me, they still maintain'd their ground,
When I withdrew to inform▪ you of your Danger,
And know your further pleasure

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O Death to all my Hopes! [Aside] Return I charge 〈…〉
If thy 〈…〉 dear to thee, with speed Return;
And tell these Scandals to the Scythian Race,
That they had better never have been born,
Than e'er behold my Evil without the Prisoner?
Tell them, they can but dieby Grecian Hands;
And if they die by them, they die with Honour,
And they who die with Honour, die with Pleasure.
But should they owe their Deaths to my Revenge,
O● Thou, O Heaven! that shouts the shout of Triumph,
●ead in my Eyes the Rest, and fly to inform them.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: The Gods apparently reject this Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How durst thou think so?

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: The prodigies so lately seen confirm it.
Scarce had the Night upon her Carr ascending,
Thrown her black Influence round the Mournful Hemisphere,
When a Mad Whirlwinds Subterranean blast,
Made the Dome tremble from its deep Foundation.
And shook the dreadful glories of its Spires.
Yet hide themselves from 〈…〉 they have given
A Spirit, worthy of the 〈…〉?
Ha! Art thou then return'd▪ What do 〈…〉 Grecians?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: The Grecians make a surely slow Retreat.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And where's the Victim?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Look where the Scythians guard him towards the Altar.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: You are just ye pow'rs in all your ways!
Now let the Rites begin.

div.stage:
The flat Scene draws and discovers the Altar, Iphigenia on the one side, and Euphrosine on the other in Mourning postures. The Victim veild is introduced by flat Trumpets, a Train of Priests and
Priestesses and Guards. The Victim is led 〈…〉; after that a dreadful Symphony, and then the following Ode.
Ode for the Sacrifice. Three Priests, Chorus of Priests and Priestesses.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: HAil great Diana, ●ear and s●●,

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Hail Moon that with thy silver Light,
Govern'st the Empire of the Night,
Look down and see,

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice to thee.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: And thou the Dreadfull'st of the three,
Hail Infernal Hecate!
Ascend and see!

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice to thee.

div.head: II.
div.l: Thee, Great Diana, thee,
Goddess renown'd for Chastity,
Thee first of all we Invoke,
To see us strike the fatal stroke.
On him who with a Heart prophane,
Thy very Altars sought to stain.
Thy presence open'd the dark Womb
And gave him Entrance to the Light;
Thy presence too must open the sad Tomb,
And send him to Eternal Night.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Thee Goddess, thee, we all invoke
To see us strike the fatal stroke.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Thou Moon that with thy Silver Light,
Govern'st the Empire of the Night;
Thee, Goddess, thee, we next Invoke,
To see the fatal stroke.
As Horrour thou art pleas'd to see,
Horror loves to g●●● on thee.
Each Fiend, and ev'ry ghastly Spright
That so abhors thy Brother's Ray,
Yet oft forsakes eternal Night
To revel in thy paler Day.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Thee, Goddess, Thee we next invoke,
Look down and see the fatal Stroke.

sp.speaker: 2 Chor.
sp.l: She sees, she sees, a gloomy Red
Has half her glowing Face o'erspread.
But, oh behold, o'er half her Light,
Some Charm dresses gloomy Night;
It must be some Thessalian Charm,
〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 your Trumpets, give the alarm;
Let ●●● 〈…〉 the Sky,
〈…〉 your Drums,
A●●●●● the Victim die.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: But hold, till lastly thee,
〈◊〉 Hecate!
Queen of Furies we invoke,
Ascend and see the fatal Stroke.
Ascend from everlasting Night,
Blasting Nature with the sight;

div.head: VI.
div.l: She comes, she cleaves the trembling Ground,
And spreading horrour all around,
D●●●ly dies the misty Air,
Her dark and gri●●ly Features fright,
The coal black Steeds that drag the Night,
And Nature's Centinels they scare,
Heark how with dreary Shriek the Owl,
And▪ frighted Wolves with dreadful Howl,
Her dire approach declare.

sp.speaker: Chorus:
sp.l: She's here, her Guard of Furies se●,
And Furies now as great are we,
Her Spirit rages in our Souls,
And in our frantick Eyes it rowls.
To the dismal Deed she's come to excite us,
And nothing but Blood can delight us;
Give us Blood, give us Blood,
Give us a Flood,
Let it flow, let it flow,
Strike, strike the fatal Blow.

div.stage: A shout just as the Ode ends.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh insolence, audacious, insupportable!
Look out and see who 'tis that dares disturb
The Execution of this dreadful Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Great Queen, provide betimes for your security,
The Greeks returning, bear down all before them,
And the next moment will invest the Temple.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Are all the Gates madefast?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: They'r all with Bars of solid Brass secur'd.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Then I'll prevent them, Priestess do thy Duty.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Goddess, look down, thy Priestess is thy Victim.

div.stage: Offers to stab herself, the Victim throws off his Veil, and 〈…〉 the Knife from her, discovering himself to be Pilades; 〈…〉 same time speaking as follows.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oh hold, 'tis Sacrilege to strike that stroke,
Thy Beauties are the Darling care of Heav'n;
Look up, and see the Wonder it has wrought
On purpose to preserve them.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: May I believe my Eyes! Amazing sight!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Miraculous Events!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Thou thought'st to die for the dear Man thou lov'st,
And I, alas, am come to die for him.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O all ye Pow'rs whose Wisdom rules the Universe,
Let me adore the Wonders of your Providence!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Revenge thy, injur'd Handmaid, great Diana!
Revenge thy injur'd self, we're both betray'd,
By my own faithless Subjects we're betray'd.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: No, cruel Queen, thou see'st I am come to die,
And satisfie you both.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Where is thy Friend?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Where! at the Head of his Victorious Grecians.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh, cursed Fate!
What brought thee here, to suffer in his stead?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Agreement with your Scythians, and desire
To save the only Man of all the World,
That's fit to be a Friend, by gaining time
Enough for his Embarkment.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What hast thou said? Agreement with my Scythians?
Oh the vile Traitors! Why should they agree to it?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: To save themselves.
After our Greeks had forced my God-like Friend from them,
They who soon found their Victim irretrievable,
And knew what torments they must undergo,
Unless they could make you think they had retriev'd him,
They who with Wonder had beheld the Pow'r
Of 〈…〉 Friendship in my Friend and me,
To my Apartment come half dead with fear,
Where they inform'd me of our Greatest Valour,
Your Threats, their baseness, and my Friend's escape,
I 〈…〉 gain time for his Embarkment,
〈…〉 and die for him.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: 〈…〉 the Altar thus unbound?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: 〈…〉 I agreed with them.
Death 〈…〉 embrac'd,
But the 〈…〉 of a Slave,
My free ●●●● soul disdain'd▪
〈…〉 Was ever any thing thing so great?
〈…〉 And yet so tender and so true?
〈…〉 me Grecian, but so nobly,
〈…〉 beauteous as thy Fraud,
〈…〉 that thou must die,
〈…〉 a God like Action!
〈…〉 ●he! Must he die for it?
〈…〉 it all ye Pow'rs!
〈…〉 selves inspir'd this wondrous Virtue,
〈…〉 least, he ne'er shall die.
〈…〉. But die th●●●●st;
〈…〉 Rites, and great Revenge require it.
〈…〉 thy Office.
〈…〉 O● never, never!
〈…〉. Ah, miserable Creature! think with trembling,
What Vengeance thou art drawing on thy Head.
●●● the time presses, I shall be prevented,
●ake thou the sacred Steel, and strike the Blow.

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Make way for the Elder of the Captives there, Make way.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: For the Elder of the Captives!

div.stage: As the other Priestess is going to strike, Orestes enters, runs between the Dagger and Pilades, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: He lives, he lives, I have him in my Arms,
This turn, ye Pow'rs, has made amends for all.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Confusion! I am lost, the Greeks are here,
Strike thro' them both.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ah, cruel fight! Ah, Gods! I cannot bear it.
Thus, let me intercept the barbarous Blow.

div.stage: As the other Priestess goes to strike, Iphigenia interposes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: O Death and Vengeance! Her, her Heart transfix.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Who's the chief Priestess?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hers, lift thy executing Arm, haste, strike,
I'm lost, undone, on every side betray'd,
And the next moment we shall be prevented.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O hurt not her, by Heav'n and Earth I adjure you▪
●o● I am come alone, and come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What say'st thou? 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: 'Tis certain.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Wert thou not Rescued by thy Friends?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I was▪

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Hast thou been retaken then by our Scythians?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Your Scythians are dispers'd, and we are Victors.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Where are thy Grecians then?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Upon the horrid sommet of the Cliff,
By my Command, obsequiously they wait.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How got you entrance?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: At the Iron Wicket of the Postern, where
Arm'd with a hundred Javelins, Death stands Centry,
And none can there unlicens'd pass and live.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What brought thee to this fatal place alone?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thou com'st to die! the Conquerour comes to die!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: After our Greeks had forced me from your Scythians,
And the short Fury of the Fight was past;
As soon as the Retreat we slowly made,
Had giv'n me time for thought;
My Joy soon vanish'd all, for soon I found
That I had left all that I held most precious,
All that was dear to my afflicted Soul,
Ev'n in the Jaws of Fate,
Strait I prevail'd upon my valiant Friends
T'attempt a second Rescue.
Then to my Friend's Apartment we all flew,
To force his Guards, the Guards indeed we forc'd,
But him we found not, there I grew inform'd
Of his deplorable, tho' God▪ like purpose;
That his inimitable Love for me
Made him to a bloody doom devoted stand,
At these inhumane Altars.
Swift as a Storm we hurried to the Temple,
But when I found the Massy Gates all barr'd,
The dreadful Rites begun, and my poor Friend
At the Altar, and about to breath his last,
To breath his last for me;
Witness ye Pow'rs, that thought I could not bear,
With rigorous Commands I enjoyn'd my Friends
To leave me to the adverse Gods and Fate.
For Gods and Fate cry'd out that I must bleed,
Or else surviving ev'ry minute die▪
My Friends unwilling▪ yet with Tears obey'd;
And here alone the Conquerour's's come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Unheard of Friendship!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Unexampled Faith!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: O Constancy Divine!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Was 〈◊〉 ●●●n so great a sight
Of glorious Woe before!

sp.speaker: Euph. to Iph.
sp.l: Courage, my Princess, for the Gods declare for us,
They are here among us▪ they are manifest;
For these are plainly more than Human Actions▪

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am o'recome, I yield y' Almighty Powers,
To hurt such Virtue were to touch your selves,
Such Virtue is Divinity.
Here, set them free immediately.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The Grecians.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Both?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Both.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Then, where's the Victim for our Solemn Rites?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The Goddess has herself declar'd her Victim.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Enquire no more, but set thy Prisoners free.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: They are free.

sp.speaker: Queen▪ to Or.
sp.l: Grecian I need not be asham'd to own
That I am charm'd by thy exalted Virtue.
The Immortal Powers themselves are fond of less.
Twice in one night has it prevail'd upon me
To give thee Life, to give thee Liberty;
But since thou shew'st thou valuest not thy own,
I here bestow thy Friends upon thee too.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: From my soul▪ I thank you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But Custom, which▪ 〈◊〉 Scythians Law▪ requires▪
That they whom my Prerogative▪ ●●●s free,
Must become Scythians▪ by Espousing Scythians▪
Or—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: But Liberty in that too will be necessary.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: As free as is the Wind shall be thy choice:
Thou shalt be forc'd in nothing, yet permit me▪
To give thy Wife a Dowry worthy thee.
Thy Souls surpassing greatness I admire!
Which Heaven that form'd it sure design'd for Empire;
Accept of mine, thy wiser nobler Sway
Will polish these Barbarians into Men.
Thine are the vast extended Plains of Tauris.
My self, my Subjects, Men and Women, all
Shall govern'd be by thy unbounded Sway;
The Soveraign Partner of thy Royal Bed
Among a thousand Scythian Beauties choose,
And make her happy who's most worthy thee.
Then I am lost again.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Art thou not mov'd?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Amaz'd, confounded, Gods! Are these the words
Of a Barbarian, of a Savage Scythian?
But, be she what she will
Such generous Passion I ne'r knew till now,
No, not in Greece, but oh its Artful modesty!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What, no reply?
My Present sure deserves at least your Thanks.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh! It deserves much more than I can pay!
Oh! It deserves my Heart, my very Soul:
And now, ev'n now I ought to be beheld
Paying my Adorations at your Feet;
And off'ring all my self with fervent Vows.
But oh! have pitty on so lost a Creature,
Who has no Heart, no Soul, no Vows to pay,
Who has given all these, who has given himself away
A Voluntary Slave, one so accurst,
That though he mortally detests Ingratitude,
Yet wants the power, nay wants the very will
To pay th' Immense acknowledgment he owes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Suppose some God should free you from this Passion?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I wish not to be free:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet put the Case you were this moment free,
Might I expect to find you grateful then?
For Grecian, I am loth to think you hate me.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hate you! O Heaven! of all your lovely Sex
You I esteem, and you I most admire,
Should I say more, I basely should deceive you.
To wrong you in that Nature, that indeed
Would be the height of black ingratitude.
For all my softer thoughts another claims;
Who, though the tenderest of her gentle Sex,
Yet has a Tyrants force upon my Soul.
But were I not prevented by that Passion,
Now Prostrate at your Feet you should behold me,
Prouder to obey your absolute Commands
Than to Controul th' extended Plains of Tauris.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, could I haue resolv'd to say what's false,
You had heard a falshood that would more have pleas'd you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: But swear.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Propose the Oath.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Swear by the dreadful Altar you have escap'd.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: By this Tremendous Altar then I swear.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: This Altar then shall free that from a Passion
That's so unworthy thee, 〈◊〉 like the Priestess,
For her the Goddess 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 her Victim.
Here, take 〈◊〉, bind 〈◊〉 drag her to the Altar,
And in her 〈◊〉 some plunge the Sacred Steel.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: O Heaven! The Priestess!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Impious Proposal!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Think not that we will e're endure that sight.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Think not that you'll endure it! Think where you are.
You both are in my power.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: They who dare die are always in their own.
Our Breasts shall intercept th' accursed blow.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Guards, 'tis your Duty to take care of that.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: No barbarous power can force us to survive her.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Die then, and prove the Plagues which for the Perjur'd
The direful Goddesses prepare below,
As soon as she expires, thou to be mine
Hast by th' inviolable Altar sworn.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: In what a Mase, O Fate, am I entangled!
But think, reflect, by all the Gods I adjure you.
And Oh regard that lovely dying Face,
Meek and resign'd in these extreamest Sufferings.
Oh look and stop th' Abominable Blow!
Mercy, sweet Mercy will it self
Be murder'd by that Blow.
Look, cast your Eyes around, behold a sight
Enough to dissolve Flint, see these Barbarians
Whose Eyes have been inur'd to ghastly Murder,
Whose Crimson Arms are dy'd with horrid Grain,
Ev'n they Dissolve, they me●● their Eyes shed Tears,
Those Cruel Eyes that never 〈◊〉 before.
Look how they're seiz'd with hidden Horror all!
But above all look up, be hold your Goddess!
Think that you see her 〈◊〉 wrathful Frown
Denouncing Plagues on your Devoted Heads!
Think that already her avenging Arms
Are lifted, and prepare the dreadful Judgments
That must be pour'd on this accursed Race,
Revenging with its utter extirpation,
Her Priestess Murder'd, and here Shrine prophan'd.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Scythians, 'tis true.
These Judgments we must fearfully expect
If we lay impious Hands upon the Priestess.

sp.speaker: All Scyth.
sp.p: Unbind the Priestess, set her free immediately.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hear me first, Scythians, and you Grecians hear!
Scythians, what slavish Doubt has seiz'd your Souls?
What fear you? To provoke the dreadful Goddess!
This is her Victim; she her self has claim'd her;
Nay, and with so much vehemence has claim'd her,
She left th' Immortal Mansions of blest Beings
On purpose to demand her, and too long
This Priestess has already liv'd Devoted to her.
I till this hour, forgive it awful Goddess,
I by a Tender weakness mov'd, preserv'd her;
And Heaven best knows how I have been rewarded.
Now for you, Grecians, you too shall be satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: No, never, if she dies.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes, though she dies, for when you know this Priestess
You will your selves demand and urge her Fate.
At least if you're the Sons of those brave Grecians
Who carried their Heroick Arms to Asia,
And with a thousand Sail Beleaguer'd Troy.
With one accord your Fathers urg'd her Fate,
Nay her own Father to the Altar doom'd her,
Because the severe Goddess had exacted her.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: May I believe my Sense? Am I awake!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O all y' Immortal Powers! How am I tortur'd
By the fierce pangs of wondrous Expectation!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But Death by her Mothers Artifice she escap'd,
While a young Lesbian Slave in Shape and Size
And Age resembling hers, in a long Veil
Was at the Altar offer'd in hear stead.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Support me! Gods! Support me!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why dost thou thus exclaiming interrupt me?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh! I have most amazing things to tell you!
But first Important Questions I must ask.
I have Important things t' enquire of her.
And Queen, assure thy self on what I say
Thy Peace, thy lasting Happiness depends.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Speak, but be short then, what are the Gods doing!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Say then, poor, lost, abandon'd Virgin, say,
Didst thou from bleeding at a Grecian Altar
By thy fond Mothers Artifice escape!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I did, and thank the Gods a thousand times for it;
By that escape I have liv'd to dye for thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Talk not of Death, alas, but answer me,
O thou art sure the▪ Darling Care of Providence,
And it has wrought prodigious things to save thee!
How comes it that thy strange Escape▪ in Greece
Was never heard or talk'd of●

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Of 〈…〉 wretched Parents
Were 〈…〉 it, 〈…〉 night inform'd me
They sadly 〈…〉 by a 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O Miracle of 〈…〉 O Transport▪

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: My Sisters both werein 〈…〉 Infancy,
My Brother scarce had seen the 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: By Heav'n and Earth it can be none but 〈…〉,
See Helens Form upon that lovely Front!
Answer but one thing more, say from what Altar
Didst thou escape, and by what Artifice?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Alas 'tis a long Story,
And my weak Spirits, by my Grief opprest,
Will let me say no more.
But in my Cabinet it large 'tis written,
Yet grant me this, my first and last Request,
To Greece transport the Writing.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Talk not of Writings, Writings may be lost;
But tell me in a word what I must say,
What and to whom?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Inform my Friends and Kindred then at Argos,
That the forlorn abandon'd 〈…〉—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O supreme Jove, whose Providence has wrought this!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What makes you lift your 〈…〉 to Heaven,
And starting thus exclaim?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Was ever Vision of the Night so strange,
So wonderful as this! Say on, say on.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Tell them at Argos, that poor Iphigenia,
Whom fondly they believ'd at 〈…〉 sacrific'd,
Escap'd the Altar there▪ but that the Goddess
Upon the Shore of Tauris found her Victim.
And with, O wish my Brother, my Orestes,
A much more gentle Fate!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Thus, thus, thy Brother, thy Orestes thanks thee.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: My Brother! Oh!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: My dearest Sister!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can it be true!
Or does my Sense, grown wild with Grief, delude me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Her Brother! is it possible! her Brother!

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.p: Her Brother! and the powerful King of Argos▪

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is't possible! O the transporting Joy!
Impetuous Flood of unexpected Rapture!
Whether I live or no I cannot tell.
Haste, Scythians, haste, upon your knees unbind her.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Hold off your barbarous hands, presumptuous Slaves,
And let a Prince be honour'd with that Task.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O Queen! O Friend! O Sister!
Was ever Night like this!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Thus to these lovely Limbs I Liberty restore.
O would but the good Gods and she consent
That I for ever might remain a Captive.

sp.speaker: Qu. to Iph.
sp.l: Canst thou forgive me all this cruel Usage,
Of which Love only could have made me guilty?
Canst thou, thou tend'rest of all Humankind?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Can you so much as ask it? all my Soul
Is to transporting Tenderness resign'd.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou art all Goodness; in this strict Embrace
Let all Unkindness be forgot for ever.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Now, how shall we pay equal Thanks to Heav'n,
For this so great, so wonderful Deliverance?
Chiefly with flaming Zeal our Thanks to thee,
To thee our Thanks we pay, Divine Apollo!
And thy unerring Oracle adore.
Next, let me pay my Debt to thee, my Pilades,
And with the best of Sisters let me bless
The kindest, truest and the best of Friends.
She cannot now be mine, and ne'er shall be anothers,
Take her my Friend, thou art my very self,
The other, dearer Half of thy Orestes.
Take her, and with her take ten thousand Joys,
All the high Raptures thy fierce Passion promises▪
Thou answer'st not.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oh, I want Breath to speak, I die with Ecstasie!
And my tumultuous Thoughts above all Words are rais'd▪
Here let me with dumb Eloquence express 'em,
Here pour out the abundance of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: And next to you, great Queen, I pay my Acknowledgments,
And now with Joy accept this Realm of Tauris,
That at your Feet you may behold a Slave
With two Imperial Sceptres.
And now prepare to leave this barbarous Clime,
Here but by Deputy henceforward reign,
The Gods such Worth design'd to govern Greece,
To shine the Glory of the bravest Nation,
And give example to a Race of Heroines,
Who have Force to follow so sublime a Pattern.
Your Goddess is the Partner of your Voyage.
Whose Image great Apollo's Delphic Oracle▪
Has with reiterated Voice demanded.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The Prodigies of this stupendous Night,
And Vision of the last confirm that Oracle.
With me the Goddess shall to Greece remove,
And these inhumane Rites shall cease for ever.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Gods are good, and Lovers of Mankind,
And that Religion that allows of Cruelty
Is not divine, but impious and abominable.
Lastly our Thanks once more we pay to thee,
Son of immortal Jove, divine Apollo,
Who hast made good thy bounteous Oracles.
We are preserv'd, and mighty Love preserves us.
Now, from this wond'rous Night let Mortals learn,
When in obedience to the Gods they tread
The doubtful Paths of Destiny, to affront
The dreadfullest Dangers with a dauntless Spirit.
Let 'em not ev'n in worst Extreams despair;
For while they keep to Virtue's narrow Paths,
With Guards invincible they march surrounded.
The Gods who surely guide them on the way,
From them no more than from themselves can stray,
For Virtue's of Divinity a Ray.

div.head: EPILOGUE, by Coll. Codrington.
div.l: OUR Bard shall end to night, as He began,
Prologue, Play, Epilogue shall speak the Man,
Shew a more Tragick Poet if you can.
With Pride he owns that he would gain your Hearts,
But he will use no little Whorish Arts.
With Pride he owns, that 'tis his glorious Aim
To court and to possess the Tragick Dame.
How can he court, or how can be possess,
Who shames the Goddess by a forein Dress?
That decks her like a trivial merry Muse,
Or a rank Strumpet, strolling from the Stews.
Yet thus disguis'd she oft has here been shown,
To all her genuine Votaries unknown,
Yet still you thought the motly Garb her own.
Oft have you seen her with the Comick Muse,
Walk hand in hand, Grimace and Posture use,
Debase her Majesty and Terror lose.
What needs such Art your kind Applause to win
What need such Farce to drive away your Spleen,
Who thus are pleas'd have Farce enough within.
Our Bard resolves to steer a diff'rent Course,
And travel upwards to the Grecian Source.
Where he at first saw the chast, awful Maid,
And with observing Eyes her Charms survey'd.
Those Charms he would with a bold hand express,
Nor make 'em ●ainter by an English Dress.
To please the Great, the Gen'rous, and the Fair,
Shall ever be his Pride, and be his Care.
Next he would stand the knowing Criticks Test,
To Fortune unconcern'd he leaves the rest.
For well he knows the Ignorant and the Base
Scatter in waste their Censure and their Praise.
